Posted: June 27, 2014
												The hardy pioneers who traveled west in their covered wagons faced many dangers: weather, dangerous river crossings, bears, narwhals, machine gun bandits, diseased monkeys, lava, malevolent glitches... Now you, too, can experience this historically accurate retelling of how the West was won.In terms of gameplay, it's a short but replayable, increasingly silly series of mini-games with many variations on shooting and dodging obstacles. I've been laughing enough at even a few minutes' play of this -- four fatal encounters with the above and more -- that I've gotten my money's worth already. You can appreciate this game more if you've played "The Oregon Trail", but it's not necessary.

Posted: June 27, 2014
												This is a game that does everything right gameplaywise in the sense that your mistakes are (usually) the only reason you lost health/died, your choices are the only things getting you into sticky situations, and your knowledge and skill at and of the game is the only determining factor in how far you get. You're going to die quickly your first few times, and that's okay. This game is what many NES games were/should have been in the sense that it's not made to be beaten in a day, the same reason Castlevania is such a great game. You have to play it, fail, find out what you did wrong and learn from it, and you'll find yourself improving with every run. This never gets repetitive, as every run is different, with millions upon millions of different sets of events you could find your party going through, and more wagons being unlocked. Which wagon you choose out of your arsenal is up to you, you may choose a faster wagon to dodge projectiles, you may choose a wagon with a better weapon to fight off more enemies, or you may just go with the standard wagon because it's what works best for you. This is a game that lets you play it your way, choosing the path your party takes as you travel through a noticeably stranger 1830-1870's America, bobbing your head to the beat of the excellent soundtrack and giving a satisfied sigh at the NES-era graphics through this game, a game that gets my 10 out of 10.

Posted: June 23, 2014
												Super Amazing Wagon Adventure is a game where you create a party of three to ride a wagon to migrate west.  It alternates between a side scroller (when you're in the wagon) and being able to wander around on the screen to acomplish a task (on foot)  Most of the time you're going to be trying to avoid death by shooting various enemies with an assortment of weapons.  But you don't get this game for the gameplay you get it for the story.  While you will figure out the general format after a bit of playing the game will still continue to through curve balls at you.  This game will kill you and your other 2 friends  in ways you never expected such as unicorn magic, UFOs, and your inner demons to name a few.  Be prepared to die a lot.  My only complaint is that there is no mouse sensitivity adjustment, so in game my mouse is has very low sensitivity which is annoying.  Fortunatly the game can be played with only a keybord and doesn't require a mouse.9.6/10

Posted: June 26, 2014
												I set off with myself, my adopted Jamaican uncle JoJo, and my platonic female friend Sexjoke.We realize we need food, meat specifically, to keep our spirits hardy during the long journey. We kill countless animals and store their corpses in our wagon, we will eat well...My company and I come across a legendary beast of old. The magestic yet misleading unicorn. Our feast for flesh knows no limits, so I consider killing the beast for food. I, being the leader, decide otherwise. "No!" I tell my companions. "We shall follow this beast, and see will it takes us!"Ah unicorns are shifty beasts are they not? The magestic animal had led us into an ambush, and its brothers and sisters charged at us, their horns thirsting for blood. We fend them off and pick up their corpses for meat.We thought it was over, but suddenly a ferocious cross between a snake, a bird of prey, and a big cat comes out of nowhere to send us to meet our maker. A dragon! It breathes flaming hot fire onto our wagon, burning JoJo and I to death.Haunting the cart, I watch as Sexjoke valiantly defeats the vile creature. I've never been more proud.Mourning our deaths, she came across a roaring river, she could ford it, but she could attempt to jump over it.She chooses the latter, but miraculously survives, only to land in a family of bears, waking them from their slumber.One of them runs up to Sexjoke and hugs her, the force of said hug causes the poor lady to explode.Our journey is over, but we unlocked Fiona's wagon from Shrek.(10/10) Would die again...

Posted: June 27, 2014
												Is this game great? No.Is it fun? For a while.Is it hard? Artificially, yes. (Undodgeable objects, inability to heal outside of random chance, random drops in health via disease.)Is it roguelike? Partially. There are random events but only a select few that always occur at the same positions. Example is at the beginning you either get ambushed by Unicorns and fight a dragon or you get ambushed by bandits and fight a machine gun cart. Is this game entertaining? For a while, then it gets infuriatingly repetitive and boring as you never quite reach the end due to dumb luck. It would also be nice if the other carts weren't god awful or impossible to unlock. Reward players, don't cripple them when the odds are already stacked against them. EDIT: One really great thing about this game is the soundtrack. Even if the game is repetitive the soundtrack is enjoyable every time. The Great Plains music reminds me of the early days of Ninja Sex Party. Also the soundtrack is in the games files with remixes not in the game, so drop it into your music player of choice if you want to listen on the go.Do I recommend this game? Only on a sale. It is fun and it's a goofy game to introduce to friends. But it's basically a Newgrounds Flash Game, probably won't entertain past an 30min, an hour tops. $3 isn't bad but I've gotten better for free.

Posted: June 27, 2014
												This game is awesome, yet historically acurate.It narrates the short journey that those brave men and women took on the Wild West on the 19th century.As real people, they fought illneses, wolves, bandits, unicorns, laser weapons... And, that's how i remember history.The game is pretty fast, It mixes classic shoter scenes with ones with one of your oh so acurate travelers on foot, involved on looking for stuff, either to eat or to declare loves.Also, the variety of weapons is awesome. One second you are killing buffalos with a pistol, the other you have a flamethrower. Or a bow. Or a falcon, Or something like a bullet-train.To sum up: get the game if you still havent.And, If you excuse me, I'll try to save my adventurers yet again (hopefully unsuccesfully)

Posted: January 10, 2016
												I love this game so much! It's kinda similar to the Oregon Trail (On MS DOS) but with so much more! You'll encounter Unicorns, Strange Space Machines, Pirates, and even Machine-Gun weilding Bandits! This game has everything! However the only thing I would like changed is how relationships can occur. Sometimes on your journey a party member will fall in love with another party member. I like this feature as it adds an extra layer to the randomness of this game. My only complaint with this is that you can't disable same-gender couples. On one of my journeys one of my party members (He was a guy and my best friend IRL) fell in love with my character (Who was also a guy). This didn't change too much but I was annoyed that I couldn't disable it. Other than that this is an amazing game set at an amazing price and you should try it out!

Posted: May 3, 2016
												Hilarious and surprisingly hard, this game is like Oregon Trail on drugs.  I played this game for over 12 hours and only beat it a couple of times, but it's so fun you won't even care about losing. With lots of different wagons to unlock and a semi-random progression, which is partially influenced by the player's choices, and the number of times you'll just lose, this game has a pretty high replay value.  At a price of $2.99, you'll never get so much for so little elsewhere. BUY THIS GAME.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												Huh, this'll be a nice relaxing sidescroller I can wind down with between other games.What the ♥♥♥♥ was I thinking.Not only is this game the most ♥♥♥♥ing frustrating game I have ever played, it is also one of the funniest thanks to its originality. Other reviews praise the game for the "Shuffle" mode which allows you to play a completely random generated journey. Shuffle mode is unlocked after the "short" Adventure Mode is completed...ATM I have over 16* hours in this game and have yet to beat this story mode. Never in my life have my mechanical keyboard and G502 been put to better use than killing 10-Pixel-People (yes) on a quest across the United States of America. (You may think this game is cheap at $3, but the investment into necessary gaming peripherals just to play the game properly, puts the cost at well over $150.)If you, like I was, are looking for a game to play between other games... think again. This will become the Game you take a break from, not the other way around. That said, the only reason you'll be taking a break is to calm down before you shatter your monitor in a rage fueled punch after you stand up and curse at the bison or bandits, once more falling victim to the endless predators of the great North America.*UPDATE: I have beaten the game with only 38 hours playing time. Shuffle mode is insane, totally not worth my time and effort.

Posted: December 25, 2014
												Oddly replayable.  Super Amazing Wagon Adventure plays like a NES game.   It's simple pixel graphics are completely justified with nice effects and an actual attempt to care.  For instance,  blood splatters, look like pixel blood splatters.    Visually, the style works.The sound is amazing too,  and I regret not bein able to find a soundtrack.What you're looking at is essential a Rogue Like.   A very fast paced one at that that is completely and utterly unforgiving.  Master the controls,  and get a rythem down for the random events allows you to survive.  So not only do you need technical skill playing, but also the fate of an RNG.   Lots of unlockables also means that while you don't get to the end each time,  you might at least pull out a new Wagon,  or discover a differnt event.    Finally, price.  You just can't beat it.  Worthwhile overall,   Are there negatives?  Not really,  apart from sometimes getting creamed too often by the random generator,   slightly off putting.   Fixable?  Sorta, but that's not the point.

Posted: October 21, 2016
												I saw this game on sale for less than a buck and said "hey, why not?"  That was probably the best decision I made that day because I am getting way more than my money's worth out of it and I can say without a doubt that it is worth more than its full price.  Granted, this is not some Earth-shattering monument of technical achievement or anything.  But for what it is, it is very fun and will provide you with hours of amusement.  For an idea of what the game itself is like, imagine Oregon Trail meets Galaga as written by Tim & Eric and directed by Mel Brooks (because that totally doesn't sound like some kind of monster).  The gameplay itself is smooth, fun, and well-varied.  Most of the things that you come across are pretty much random events (there is some overall structure; i.e. you generally pass through most of the same 'zones' in the same order, however what those 'zones' contain tends to be randomized), and there are some very interesting (and amusing) random events.  Controls are simple and responsive and it's controller-compatible, so you've got options there.  There are also a bunch of unlockables to keep you engaged for a while, including different modes of play (sadly, however, no multiplayer).Overall, this game is a really great deal if you like retro-styled side-scrolling shooter games with a heavy helping of humor.  Get it.  Play it.  Enjoy it.

One second you are killing buffalos with a pistol, the other you have a flamethrower. Or a bow. Or a falcon, Or something like a bullet-train.To sum up: get the game if you still havent.And, If you excuse me, I'll try to save my adventurers yet again (hopefully unsuccesfully)

Posted: November 24, 2016
												Bullet hell, Wild West simulator a la Oregon Trail... if you removed any reverance for the hardship of the frontier and included unrealistic, exaggerated craziness.10/10 for the price.5/5 Graphics5/5 Music4/5 Replayability5/5 Game for the priceSAWA represents, to me, the ideal cheap game. It's inexpensive, it's a game you can pick up and play for 10 minutes, but it has plenty of unlockables, divergent events, and so on.Basically each 'level' is dodging enemies or projectiles.  There are also plenty of bosses and minibosses, and each time you play is different.  What makes SAWA different is that the each event is insane, from accidentally jumping into outer space, to taking shrooms and fighting off your inner demons, or my personal favorite, fighting glitches in the game as they attack and try to break the game. There's not much to say, the replayability is great but does run dry and is completely randomized, so there's no way of knowing if you'll ever unlock some of them.  It's cheap, small, and a great time waster for a few laughs.
